Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fellow's Name: Tara M. Smiley

Proposal Number: 1612002

This award funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Tara M. Smiley is "Ecological interactions and community assembly under climate change: a Cenozoic perspective." The host institution for this fellowship is Oregon State University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Rebecca Terry.

This research evaluates the processes underpinning community assembly and persistence during two climate-warming intervals in the geologic past that differed in magnitude, rate, and environmental context. The research results will promote understanding of anthropogenic climate change, because novel climates and non-analog biotic communities will become more common as human activities rapidly change natural environments. The Fellow is examining three aspects of community ecology: 1) turnover of species at the local scale; 2) niche dynamics along body size and resource use gradients;  and 3) higher-level aggregate properties such as biomass and energy flow within communities and among functional and size classes. This research focuses on small mammals (rodents and lagomorphs) because they are taxonomically and ecologically diverse and are numerically abundant, facilitating community-level analyses in the fossil record. Small mammal communities are also indicators of ecosystem health; therefore understanding baseline ecological response to past climate warming is a priority for forecasting and minimizing biodiversity loss in the future. The Fellow is using the exceptional fossil collections from the John Day, Oregon, and Barstow, California, formations housed at the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument, the University of Washington Burke Museum, and the University of California Museum of Paleontology to answer these questions, and to generate novel ecological datasets via laser-ablation mass spectrometry and high-resolution X-ray computed microtomography (micro CT).

The Fellow is receiving training in stable isotope methods, developing niche models, using micro CT methods and datasets, and developing skills for the analytical assessment of community dynamics. To broaden participation in biology, the Fellow is mentoring undergraduate students in the collection of ecological data from museum specimens and developing an inquiry-based module on small-mammal ecology in Oregon to engage young, underserved students in biology and conservation through Oregon State University's Science and Math Investigative Learning Experiences program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Novel climates and non-analog biotic communities will become more common as anthropogenic activities rapidly change natural environments on local to global scales. This research evaluates the processes underpinning community assembly and persistence during a major climate-warming interval in the geologic past, as recorded in the exceptional fossil collections from the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument in eastern Oregon. Specifically, I am interested in evaluating two questions. First, do communities exhibit stability in aggregate properties (species richness, evenness, and energy flow) despite underlying turnover in composition and species-specific responses to climate change? In contrast, is community-level response unpredictable and dependent on the specific traits of constituent taxa or types of climate change experienced by a community? To evaluate these alternative outcomes of climate change, I have harnessed the power of museum collections to generate novel ecological datasets, or "new information" from "old specimens", from fossil assemblages spanning the Late Oligocene warming interval 27 to 24 million years ago. These small mammals are ideal for community-level research, as they represent a large, but understudied, component of the mammal fossil record; high species diversity and numerically abundant fossils make this work achievable. Small-mammal communities are also indicators of ecosystem health and represent nearly half of mammal diversity today. Therefore, understanding baseline ecological response to past climate warming is a priority for forecasting  and stalling biodiversity loss in the future.

Using high-resolution X-ray computed microtomography, I have scanned over 400 rodent teeth and skulls from the John Day Fossil Beds. From these high-resolution scans, I then cleaned and processed the tooth surfaces and, using known relationships between tooth morphology and diet based on modern measurements, categorized the diets of extinct taxa. Species-level and community-level data extracted from these scans of fossils allow us to examine shifts in diet, niche dynamics along body size gradients, and higher-level aggregate properties such as energy flow within communities and among functional and size classes. I then compared these data with the ecological responses of rodents to environmental change during other warming intervals that differ from the Late Oligocene in timing, rate and magnitude: the middle Miocene warming interval (17 to 14 million years ago) and warming today. Across these temporal scales, we find that ecological shifts and response times of rodent lineages can vary markedly, leading to complex community dynamics during pronounced environmental change. Furthermore, we find that not all body size and dietary classes respond in similar fashion, with some exhibiting greater vulnerability, and even extinction, during climate change. In today's rapidly changing world, information from the past is of critical importance for sustaining biodiversity for tomorrow.

As an NSF Postdoctoral Fellow, I sought to broaden participation in biology through the mentorship of undergraduate and graduate students in the collection of ecological data from museum specimens. I further developed a hands-on, inquiry-based activity centered on environmental change and small-mammal ecology to engage young students in biology and conservation through the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry's Science Communication Fellowship. During "Meet a Scientist" outreach activities, students at the museum were invited to imagine themselves in the field (aided by large-scale visuals) and to come fossil collecting with me (aided by a hands-on sorting activity using modern rodent teeth). Students were then encouraged to make observations (using a microscope and comparative morphology guides) about the fossils they had "collected".  From these observations, student made species identifications, learned about species ecology, and placed those animals into an environmental context based on their age in the fossil record. These activities were highly rewarding and demonstrated how climate change alters not only species richness, but also what species are present and the ecological roles they play in their environments. This outreach activity further highlighted the value of fossils, natural history collections, and scientific observations and thinking. 

In addition to funding from the National Science Foundation and support from my research mentor, Dr. Rebecca Terry, at Oregon State University, fossils housed in the natural history collections at the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument and the University of Washington Burke Museum made this research possible. I acknowledge the collectors of those fossils and the institutions, curators, and collections managers that maintain them for future research. MicroCT scanning resources at the University of Washington's Friday Harbor Laboratory also made this research possible. Results will continue to be disseminated through publications and presentations, while all scan data will become publicly available following the completion of this work.
